props.synopsis: On a remote beach in Solomon Islands, family members sort out their differences with spears.

image.altText: Geoffrey Blainey makes a hand gesture while delivering a speech

props.synopsis: In an opinion piece published in The Australian, historian Geoffrey Blainey said Indigenous people were counted in every federal census since 1901. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: We fact checked Geoffrey Blainey on counting Indigenous people in the census. Here's what we found

image.altText: Some shrubs in the foreground near a KFC restaurant, with striking red architecture.

props.synopsis: The woman says she wanted to leave the Canberra restaurant so she could pump her breasts with privacy, but she was told she needed to stay on site.

title.children: KFC discriminated against breastfeeding manager by telling her to express milk in a toilet tent, tribunal finds

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese wearing a Yes hooded sweatshirt during a press conference.

props.synopsis: This week we witnessed the beginning of managing expectations when Anthony Albanese started framing what he might say if the nation votes No on October 14, writes Patricia Karvelas.

title.children: It's brutal Politics 101, but Albanese is already prepping for the day after the referendum

image.altText: A man sits at a table covered in drinks as he waves a cigarette in his hand.

props.synopsis: A powerful village chief invited dozens of police officers to his house for a wild party. But when one of them wound up dead, it kicked off a huge scandal that threatens the unchecked power of Thailand’s authorities.

title.children: A Thai village chief invited dozens of cops for dinner. Then he allegedly told his henchman to kill one

image.altText: A for sale sign outside a suburban home

props.synopsis: A "slight uptick" in inflation is unlikely to see the Reserve Bank lift rates at its October meeting, but households facing a fixed-rate mortgage cliff are warned to brace for higher repayments.

title.children: Half a million households brace for higher interest rates by the end of the year as the mortgage cliff looms

image.altText: A primary school with a noticeboard out front that reads "Campbell Primary School".

props.synopsis: The ACT Integrity Commission is investigating education officials after a developer was denied a school building contract despite initially outscoring its rival.

image.altText: A sky light pops through the grass.

props.synopsis: Designers of "earth-sheltered" homes say interest in living underground is rising as the risk of bushfires increases and more days of extreme heat are forecast.

title.children: Why more of us are opting to live underground to escape bushfires and extreme heat

image.altText: A helicopter dropping water onto a bushfire.

props.synopsis: Under the new system, parts of Australia have already faced catastrophic warnings this fire season. But some of those alerts were wrong.

title.children: Australia's new $11m fire warning system is exaggerating the risks, ABC investigation reveals

image.altText: Jacinta Allan smiles, sitting in front of an ABC microphone.

props.synopsis: Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan will look to assemble her ministry, set her policy priorities and silence her opponents in her first weeks in the top job.

title.children: 'It's time, it's today': Jacinta Allan shares the moment she learnt Andrews was out

image.altText: A black and white collage of two women - one with short hair and one with long hair - looking at the camera

props.synopsis: Some of the disability royal commission's most compelling evidence has come from mothers who lost their children. On the eve of the final report, two mums share their stories and hopes for the future.

title.children: Nella's daughter died in disability care. She wants to make sure no-one else goes through the same pain

image.altText: An illustration of a particle and an antiparticle in purple and orange

props.synopsis: Attempts to understand why there is much more matter in the Universe than antimatter have been dealt a blow with an experiment ruling out one of the major explanations.

title.children: 'A huge puzzle': Antimatter falls just like ordinary matter, leaving the Universe's biggest mystery unsolved

image.altText: Flames above a large battery box behind a fence at night time

props.synopsis: E-scooters, e-bikes and renewable energy storage in the form of batteries are rapidly increasing in popularity, but they’re creating another problem.

title.children: Lithium batteries are increasing in popularity, but they're creating another problem

image.altText: A soldier waves a Ukrainian flag with his right hand as he holds a rifle in his left hand while standing atop a concrete block.

props.synopsis: Warfare has always been a blend of physical violence and psychological influence. In the war between Russia and Ukraine the battle of perceptions is shaping up as a fight between democracy and authoritarianism, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: The four dangerous perceptions emerging out of the war in Ukraine

props.synopsis: Townsville is emerging as Australia's new Army capital with hundreds of soldiers to be relocated over coming years, while Adelaide becomes the home of advanced land-based, long-range strike technology.

title.children: Townsville emerges as new 'capital' of Army in Defence Force shake up

image.altText: A man in a suit, seen from behind, looks at the ASX share price boards.

props.synopsis: Australia's stock market recovers from early losses after another mixed session on Wall Street overnight.

title.children: Local market recovers from early losses, new retail trade and job vacancies data to come

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas' share price is up today, by quite a lot. It's up 3 per cent right now, which puts it into the top 10 biggest movers so far. And have a look at this. It shows how the share price really started climbing after 3pm yesterday. That was when new Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson, chairman Richard Goyder, and general counsel and group executive Andrew Finch appeared before a parliamentary committee in Canberra to talk about Bilateral Air Service Agreements (i.e. Qatar airways and that whole controversy). They obviously performed well in the eyes of analysts and traders.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How did Qantas' new CEO do facing questions from MPs?

children.content: Qantas' share price is up today, by quite a lot.
It's
up 3 per cent
right now, which puts it into the top 10 biggest movers so far.
And have a look at this. It shows how the share price really started climbing after 3pm yesterday.
That was when new
Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson
, chairman
Richard Goyder
, and general counsel and group executive
Andrew Finch
appeared before a parliamentary committee in Canberra to talk about Bilateral Air Service Agreements (i.e. Qatar airways and that whole controversy).
They obviously performed well in the eyes of analysts and traders.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! It's David Chau here, with a guest blog post on the latest developments in China's beleaguered property sector. The chairman of China Evergrande has reportedly been put under police surveillance, while the embattled company's shares were suspended from trading on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKSE). Hui Ka Yan was taken away earlier this month and is being monitored at a designated location, Bloomberg reported. At this stage, it is unclear why Hui was placed under residential surveillance — a measure which falls short of a formal detention or arrest. Earlier this month, several employees of Evergrande’s wealth management unit were arrested in Shenzhen on unspecified charges. Evergrande is the world's most heavily indebted property developer, with around $US300 billion in total liabilities. Most of its debt is owed to people within China, many of whom are ordinary citizens whose off-the-plan apartments have not been finished. At its peak, Evergrande was the top-selling Chinese property developer, but now finds itself at the centre of China's property crisis. It has supposedly been on the brink of collapse for the past two years. Since then, a long list of property firms have been revealed to be in financial difficulty — struggling to pay off their debts — including Country Garden. Adding to the list of its woes, Evergrande's mainland unit Hengda Real Estate has defaulted on 4 billion yuan ($860 million) worth of debt. On Sunday, Evergrande told the HKSE that it was unable to sell new debt as part of its restructuring plan because Hengda was under investigation by authorities. Shares of Evergrande have plunged 38.5% to 32 Hong Kong cents over the past week. Looking further back, its share price has plummeted 98.5% in the past five years (from a high of roughly $HK22). In other words, the company's shares are almost worthless as fresh doubts emerge about its future, and whether China's government is now prepared to allow Evergrande to collapse. If so, it would likely have a significant impact on China's property prices (and social stability) since the property sector makes up around 25% of its economy.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shares of China Evergrande suspended as chairman is placed under police watch

children.content: Good morning! It's David Chau here, with a guest blog post on the latest developments in China's beleaguered property sector.
The chairman of
China Evergrande
has reportedly been put
under police surveillance, while the embattled company's shares were suspended from trading on the
Hong Kong Stock Exchange
(HKSE).
Hui Ka Yan
was taken away earlier this month and is being monitored at a designated location, Bloomberg reported.
At this stage, it is unclear why Hui was placed under residential surveillance — a measure which falls short of a formal detention or arrest.

props.alt: A Chinese businessman in a black suit and red tie looks at his audience in a conference hall.

children.content: Evergrande chairman Hui Ka Yan is under police surveillance.
(Reuters: Bobby Yip)
Earlier this month, several employees of Evergrande’s wealth management unit were arrested in Shenzhen on unspecified charges.
Evergrande is the world's most heavily indebted property developer, with around $US300 billion in total liabilities.
Most of its debt is owed to people within China, many of whom are ordinary citizens whose off-the-plan apartments have not been finished.
At its peak, Evergrande was the top-selling Chinese property developer, but now finds itself at the centre of China's property crisis.
It has supposedly been on the brink of collapse for the past two years.
Since then, a long list of property firms have been revealed to be in financial difficulty — struggling to pay off their debts — including
Country Garden
Adding to the list of its woes, Evergrande's mainland unit
Hengda Real Estate
has defaulted on 4 billion yuan ($860 million) worth of debt.
On Sunday, Evergrande told the HKSE that it was unable to sell new debt as part of its restructuring plan because Hengda was under investigation by authorities.
Shares of Evergrande have plunged 38.5% to 32 Hong Kong cents over the past week.
Looking further back, its share price has plummeted 98.5% in the past five years (from a high of roughly $HK22).
In other words, the company's shares are almost worthless as fresh doubts emerge about its future, and whether China's government is now prepared to allow Evergrande to collapse.
If so, it would likely have a significant impact on China's property prices (and social stability) since the property sector makes up around 25% of its economy.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The value of Brickworks shares has taken a beating this morning after posting a 32% drop in underlying net profit after tax to $508 million for the year ended 31 July 2023. Its statutory net profit after tax (which includes significant items from discontinued operations) was down 54%, from $854 million to $395 million. The company declared a final dividend of 42 Australian cents per share. For its Building Products Australia division, earnings before interest and depreciation was $100 million for the year, down 13%. Brickworks managing director Lindsay Partridge said: "Despite a significant decrease in new residential construction projects being commenced, demand was resilient throughout the year, with a large backlog of work under construction. "However, our margins decreased as a result of cost pressures across the supply chain. Across Austral Bricks, unit electricity costs were up 28% year on year, labour was up 13% and maintenance was up 12%. "Fortunately, our brick operations are protected from raw material input cost increases, through our direct ownership of clay quarries. "In our Concrete Products and Bristile Roofing businesses, where we source raw materials such as sand and cement from external suppliers, our unit raw materials costs were up by around 20%." Share price this morning:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Brickworks drops 10 per cent

children.content: The value of
Brickworks
shares has taken a beating this morning after posting a
32% drop in underlying net profit
after tax
to $508 million
for the year ended 31 July 2023.
Its
statutory net profit
after tax (which includes significant items from discontinued operations)
was down 54%, from $854 million to $395 million.
The company declared a final dividend of 42 Australian cents per share.
For its
Building Products Australia division
, earnings before interest and depreciation was $100 million for the year, down 13%.
Brickworks managing director Lindsay Partridge
said:
"Despite a significant decrease in new residential construction projects being commenced, demand was resilient throughout the year, with a large backlog of work under construction.
"However, our margins decreased as a result of cost pressures across the supply chain. Across
Austral Bricks
, unit electricity costs were up 28% year on year, labour was up 13% and maintenance was up 12%.
"Fortunately, our brick operations are protected from raw material input cost increases, through our direct ownership of clay quarries.
"In our Concrete Products and Bristile Roofing businesses, where we source raw materials such as sand and cement from external suppliers, our unit raw materials costs were up by around 20%."
